verb.description: To deprive of citizenship; to disfranchise. rare after 17th cent.
At the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge: to ban (a tradesman) from trading with or supplying goods to the undergraduates. Now historical.
Oxford University and Cambridge University. To deprive (a student) of commons in a college. Also: (at the University of Oxford) to expel from college. Compare "discommons". Now historical and rare.
To deprive of the character of a common; to enclose (common land). Also in figurative contexts. Now rare.

origin: Late Middle English. Partly from dis- + common, and partly from dis- + common.
